1. A 17-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of unsteadiness and dizziness that have been occurring since early adolescence. These episodes last from several minutes to an hour and are often triggered by sudden head movements or physical exertion. He also reports occasional brief involuntary jerking movements in his limbs and mild slurred speech during attacks. Between episodes, he is neurologically normal with no persistent motor deficits. His family history reveals that his mother experiences similar episodic symptoms. Neurological examination outside attacks is unremarkable, but video-oculography during an episode shows gaze-evoked nystagmus. Genetic testing identifies a mutation in the FGF14 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Episodic Ataxia, Type 6. Treatment with acetazolamide has reduced the frequency and severity of his episodes.
